items.content:
Tule.SLO
Kerndoel 54 Kunstzinnige oriëntatie

De leerlingen leren beelden, muziek, taal, spel en beweging te gebruiken,
om er gevoelens en ervaringen mee uit te drukken en om er mee te communiceren.

IPC

MP3: Zo zien zij de wereld - Kunst

Kunst 3.3

De leerlingen zijn in staat om een groot aantal verschillende materialen, vormen en technieken te gebruiken om uitdrukking te geven aan hun emoties, waarnemingen en ervaringen

Kunst 3.4

De leerlingen zijn in staat om dingen tot uitdrukking te brengen door middel van visuele en tactiele vormen

Muziek 3.4

De leerlingen zijn in staat om gecontroleerd en in het juiste ritme gestemde en nietgestemde instrumenten te bespelen

Muziek 3.5

De leerlingen zijn in staat om als onderdeel van een ensemble muziek uit te voeren

Muziek 3.7

De leerlingen zijn in staat om stukjes te componeren en daarbij muzikale elementen binnen een structuur te combineren

Muziek 3.11

De leerlingen zijn in staat om muziekwerken te interpreteren en te beoordelen op sfeer, structuur, plaats en tijd.

Activiteit 1 = Een activiteit waarbij leerlingen leren om muziekwerken te interpreteren en te beoordelen op sfeer, structuur, plaats en tijd.

Activiteit 2 = Carnival des animaux met schilderijen. Herkennen van dieren in muziekstukken. Tevens Walt Disney en Peter and the Wolf. Herkennen van karakters in muziek.

Activiteit 3 = Een activiteit waarbij leerlingen leren over de kenmerken van impressionisme en om een impressionistisch kunstwerk te maken.

Activiteit 4 = Een activiteit waarbij leerlingen leren over de Japanse drukkunst en waarbij zelf een kunstwerk wordt gemaakt door middel van het gebruiken van een linosnede.

Activiteit 5 = Een activiteit waarbij leerlingen leren over de kunststijl 'Kubisme' en hoe dit te verwerken in een kunstwerk.

Game: Running Dictation about the instruments that can be found in an orchestra
Challenge: To be the quickest and the most accurate

Vocabulary:

Classical music, Orchestra, High notes, low notes, instruments, violins, cellos, double basses, piccolos, oboes, flutes, harp, piano, clarinets, bassoons, gong, cymbals, bassdrum, snaredrum, tuba, trombones, trumpets, triangle, xylophone, glockenspiel.

Instructions
- Teacher makes two versions of the same text.
- Several copies of the correct version (the version that you want the pupils to finish up with) are stuck on the classroom walls at various easily accessible places.
- Pupils are divided into pairs (or threes) and each pair is given a copy of the second version of the text.
- Teacher points out the texts on the wall (and if necessary indicates which text different pairs should 'run' to).
- Teacher demonstrates with a pair by running the one of the texts, 'acting' out reading the first line and trying to remember it, running back to his partner and trying to dictate the first line / the first few words from the text on the wall - deliberately forgetting some of the words so having to go back to re-read and then come back and finish dictating. Then he indicates that his partner needs to do the running and so on.
- Teacher checks understanding and if not, re-does the demonstration!
- First pair to finish raises hand and wins!
- Countdown to start
- Teacher monitors that nobody is cheating
- First pair to finish gets 100 points (write on their sheet), 2nd pair gets 98, 3rd pair 96 and so on
- Either when everyone has finished or the majority, then pairs swap their sheets with another pair.
- Display the correct text on the screen. Pupils have to check the other pair's work against the correct version and take off 1 point for every mistake. They then write the total mark (the number of points gained according to how quickly they completed the activity minus the numbers of errors made) on the sheet and return to the other pair.
- Teacher checks who get 100, 99, 98, 97 etc. with a show of hands and awards points or stickers to the 'winning' pair(s)

Tips
- To stop pupils cheating, sellotape a blank sheet of paper over the front of each text on the wall to act as a sort of flap which pupils much lift up to read what's underneath! This prevents them reading and shouting across the room!

Variations
- Complete dictation i.e. the pair starts off with a blank sheet of paper (in this case the text needs to be only a few lines long)
- Partially filled grid
- Correct the text - they are differences between the two e.g. in terms of verbs, adjectives, tenses etc.
- Gap fill - they are gaps in the text on the desk - generally focusing on key grammatical feathers e.g. tenses, key words
- Pupils have a list of questions on their sheet and have to find and write down the answers against the relevant question
- The opposite of the one above!

Resources:

Time needed: 40 mins

Kerndoel: 54 IPC: 3.11

Description:
The pupils are considering pieces of music in terms of meaning, mood, structure, place and time. They are also investigating what kind of music musicians use to express emotions and experiences. Let the children listen to Beethoven's '5th Symphony (attachment 1). Let them answer the questions on the worksheet about the mood (attachment 2), visual aspects, and instruments of the music and video. A description of the instruments playing during Beethoven's '5th Symphony is attached for better understanding and knowledge of instruments being played (attachment 3)

To encourage children to note their findings, provide them with language support for musical expressions.

Functional language:
What instruments do you hear? Try to note them in the order in which you hear them. Which instruments are playing together? Are there any solos? Are the played notes high pitched notes or low pitched notes?

Vocabulary:
Classical music, Orchestra, High notes, low notes, instruments, violins, cellos, double basses, piccolos, oboes, flutes, harp, piano, clarinets, bassoons, gong, cymbals, bassdrum, snaredrum, tuba, trombones, trumpets, triangle, xylophone, glockenspiel.

Resources:


1 Prowise -> Bestuur -> IPC -> MP3 -> Kunst, Zo Zien Zij De Wereld -> T.S.T.W.L.T. - Music task 1

2 3

Time needed: Ongoing

Kerndoel: 54 IPC: 3.4, 3.5, 3.7

Description:

Impressionism in music was a movement among various composers in Western classical music, mainly during the late 19th and early 20th centuries."Impressionism" is a philosophical and aesthetic term borrowed from late 19th century French painting after Monet's Impression, Sunrise.

The most prominent in musical impressionism is the use of "color", or in musical term, timbre, which can be achieved through orchestration, harmonic usage, texture, etc.

Students can either listen to the music and see pictures at the same time or only listen to the music and afterwards see the pictures. One of the composers is Camille Saint-Saens who composed Carnival des Animaux. The music is like impressionism. In sheet (1) there is a description of the parts of music. The teacher can use this information in the lesson. In the video (2,3,4) you can see pictures of the animals that belong to the different sections.

Firstly the teacher plays the music and the children only listen to the music without seeing the video. The students have to write the animal they probably recognize in the music. Afterwards the teacher lets them hear the music again and they can see what animal the composer was aiming for. They can discuss why they had choosen that animal. What kind of instruments did they hear? What character do the instruments have? For example the double bass is the elephant and the cello is the swan.

optional:

The teacher could ask the students what Walt Disney did in his movies with instruments and characters. The movie Peter and the Wolf is a perfect example (5). They can watch a part of the movie. What kind of instruments could you use for the characters in the film? There are worksheets, music files of used instruments and a powerpoint in a zip (6) as additional resources to help you with the activity.

Example of the character and colour of sounds:

Peter: loose, carefree, light, playing, skipping, walking

Bird: quick, fast, light, small

Duck: slow, steady, broad movements, waddling, shaking itself

Cat: low, steady, smooth, pause to arch back

Grandfather: slow, stern, strict, heavy

Wolf: low, heavy, broad, licking lips, sniffing the air, mean looking

Hunters: alert, brave, quiet, slow, deliberate

Functional language:

Match each character and picture of an instrument with the correct name in the list, Cut out the pictures with their text and rearrange them into the correct order, listen to the music file and guess which instrument/animal it could be, Why did you choose this animal/instrument? What is the character of this instrument?

Vocabulary:

flute, oboe, clarinet, bassoon, horns, drum, timpani, percussion, violin, strings, piano, xylophone, cello, brass, woodwind

Resources:

1 2 1-7 3 8-13 4 14

Canival de animaux

5 6

Peter and the wolf

Time needed: 90 mins
Kerndoelen: 33, 54, 55, 56: IPC: Kunst 3.3, 3.4

Description:
The pupils are going to make an impressionist artwork using a locality from their neighborhood. They gather information from the web and from the video (1) to get to know as many features about impressionism as possible whereby they answer the information on the worksheet (2). With their findings, the pupils are going to make their own impressionist artwork (3) using paint and brushes.

Functional language:
Impressionist would place colours next to each other so that they would mix when viewed from a distance. Use contrasting colours.

- How would you describe impressionism?
- Why was it considered revolutionary?
- Could you name some impressionist painters
- Impressionist placed colours next to each other so that it would mix when viewed from a distance.

Vocabulary:
Painting, paintbrush, Impressionist, mixed, distance, canvas, colours, paint, palette, Impressionism, impressionist painting, impressionist painters, art.

Resources​:


1 2 3

Time needed: 120 mins
Kerndoel: 33 IPC: Kunst 3.3, 3.4

Description:
The pupils are going to be making a Japanese Printed Art using Lino foam and a chisel. Firstly, let the pupils watch a short video clip about Hokusai and Japanese Printed Art (1). Let them answer the questions about their findings. Once done, the pupils are going to be making their own Japanese style printed Art. Explain to the pupils how to carry out the activity by looking at the Prowise presentation. (1).

Functional language:
'What can you see that is the same between the paintings?', 'Transfer your sketch', 'Use a simple chisel to carve out', 'Cover the image with printing ink', 'Press your image firmly on to the paper', 'clean your Styrofoam'.

Vocabulary:
Japanese printed art, Styrofoam, paint brush, printing ink, layers, chisel, carve out, repeat.

Resources


(Attachement 1)

Time needed: 90 mins

Kerndoel: 33 IPC: Kunst 3.3, 3.4

Description:
(In advance, ask the pupils to bring a photograph of their own house and surroundings.) The pupils study the work of Georges Braque: 'Houses at L'Estaque' with the class (1) Let the children drag the words so they are familiar with the vocabulary before you start the quiz (2) Let the pupils do the quiz about Georges Braque's 'Houses at L'Estaque'. (2) Reflect the answers after completing the quiz. By doing so, discuss what the art style cubism is. Ask the children to make their own cubism drawing or painting about their house and surroundings.

Functional language:
Talk about the shapes, What shape are the houses? What shape are the roofs? What shape are the trees? What colours are used by the painter? What is used to create the 3-D shapes?

Vocabulary:
Cubes, Pyramids, Cylinders, Yellow, Brown, Green, Grey, Black.

Resources:


1 2

Tule.Slo:

Kerndoel 36 Oriëntatie op jezelf en op de wereld, mens en samenleving

De leerlingen leren hoofdzaken van de Nederlandse en Europese staatsinrichting en de rol van de burger.

Kerndoel 55 Kunstzinnige oriëntatie
De leerlingen leren op eigen werk en dat van anderen te reflecteren.
Kerndoel 56 Kunstzinnige oriëntatie
De leerlingen verwerven enige kennis over en krijgen waardering voor aspecten van cultureel erfgoed.

IPC

MP3: Zo zien zij de wereld - Kunst

Internationaal 3.5

De leerlingen kunnen uitleggen hoe het leven van mensen in het ene land of de ene groep wordt beïnvloed door de activiteiten van mensen in een ander land of een andere groep

Internationaal 3.6

De leerlingen kennen manieren waarop mensen samenwerken voor een wederzijds belang

In dit deel kunnen kinderen kennis maken met kleur geven aan je omgeving. Wat is er in de wereld gedaan om invloed uit te oefenen op de gang van zaken.

Activiteit 1 = Het werk van Unicef wordt behandeld en er kan gekeken worden naar mogelijkheden in de omgeving van kinderen zelf, om (positieve) veranderingen aan te brengen.

Activiteit 2 = De Europese Unie en de Brexit van Engeland en de mogelijke gevolgen.

Game: Find your partner (2 games - Where are you from? and Is your country a member of the EU?)
Challenge: To be the first to find their partner

Functional language:
Where are you from? I am from...., Is your country a member of the EU?, Yes, .... is a member of the EU, No, .... is not a member of the EU.
Vocabulary:
Sweden, Stockholm, Finland, Helsinki, Poland - Warsaw, Germany, Berlin, France, Paris, Luxembourg - Luxembourg, Belgium, Brussels, The Netherlands, Amsterdam, Spain, Madrid, Portugal, Lisbon, Italy, Rome, Greece, Athens, Bulgaria, Sofia, Romania, Bucharest, Austria, Vienna, Slovakia, Bratislava, Hungary, Budapest,

Instructions:
- Give every pupil a card and stress that this is secret
- You also have a card
- Demonstrate
- Ask one pupil the key question, the pupil will answer according to what is on their card (e.g. Key Question: where are you from? Pupil replies I am from............
- If the response is the same as on your card, then this is your partner. If not, then say goodbye and move on to another pupil.

- For the first game the pupils have to find their partner which matches the capital city of their country. For the second game the pupils have to end up making two groups - countries in the EU and countries not in the EU.
- Pupils then do the same i.e. going around the room asking each other the questions to find someone with the same card as them.
- Set a time limit
- Check who has found their partner and award points to teams
Tips
- When doing the demonstration, aim to pick 2 pupils with different cards to you, before eventually finding the pupil with the same card! Show the card to the class so they realize that the two cards are the same.
- Ensure they stick to the functional language by picking up on cheating / English / looking at each other's cards etc.- strategies for this include deducting team points / using language police.
Variations
- Cards can contain more than one symbol or word in order to generate a dialogue. To make it harder to find their partner many of the pairs of cards can start off in the same way e.g. where did you go on holiday? With who? For how long? How did you go?

Resources:

Time needed: 2 hours
Kerndoel: 36 IPC: 3.5, 3.6

Description:
Children will hear and see the work of Unicef and will think about their chance to change their own world. What can they do in their small world? As a starter they can see the video (3), than there is a powerpoint (with video) and information and answers for the teacher (1 and 2). There is a small video to explain that helping people can be easy (4).

Note; The teacher can adjust the lessons to the level of English of the class.

Functional language:

UNICEF's mission is:

  1. To advocate for the protection of children's rights.
  2. To help meet their basic needs.
  3. To expand their opportunities to reach their full potential.

What is the aim of this video? What do Unicef believe all children are entitled to? How can we help to contribute? What would happen if you could not go to school? What purpose do these laws serve? How much water do you think you use per day? Who remembers getting an injection when they were little? What does it mean to be malnourished? What diseases do you think have had the most damaging impact on communities in the past generation? Have you ever been excluded from participating in something? How did it make you feel? What items do you think are helpful to victims of emergencies?
Vocabulary: malnutrition, health care, clean water, nutrition, education, emergency, Education, Child Protection, Water and Sanitation, HIV and AIDS, Social Inclusion,

Resources:

1 2 3

4

Time needed: Ongoing

Kerndoel: 54 IPC: 3.5, 3.6

Description:

The children hear about the history of the EU (1), the flag, and the rights and trade in the EU. From the document they can learn/read about the importance of the EU (2).They can identify EU member states and their capitals, illustrate the key aims of the EU and identify the key conditions of EU membership. Also the advantages and disadvantages of EU membership. The children can hear about the Brexit discussion in England and the results of the referendum (powerpoint 3). Later on they can talk about why they think they will stay or leave Europ.

Functional language: Will Britain stay in or leave the European Union? Match the capital to the member, These are the five aims the EU has set out to meet, Divide your page into six boxes, Explain your view on the importance of the Netherlands' membership of the EU.

I believe that we must continue, because ..., I believe that we need to stop Europe, because ... The (dis)advantage for Europe is... The importance of the Netherlands' membership of the EU is ...

Vocabulary: Europian Union, referendum, leave or remain, a vote, Prime Minister, trade, member, citizens, the poll, capital, to buy and to sell, Promote economic and social progress, Speak for the European Union, on the international scene, develop Europe as an area of freedom, security and justice, peoples' rights, the five aims ​

1 2 3
